nodes.text: A single-kernel, pure-GPU, error-bounded lossy compressor with optimized lossless encoding, vectorized memory access, and latency-hiding can achieve extreme end-to-end throughput and improved compression ratios for HPC datasets

CUSZP2 implements a single-kernel, pure-GPU compression pipeline operating on block granularity that performs lossy conversion, lossless encoding, device-level prefix-sum, and block concatenation entirely on GPU

CUSZP2 introduces three key designs: Outlier Fixed-Length Encoding (adaptive lossless encoding), Vectorized Memory Accesses (intra-block vectorization and inter-block coalescing), and Global Prefix-sum via Decoupled Lookback (latency-hiding device-level sync)
End-to-end throughput (including all GPU intrinsic APIs and memory operations) is the appropriate metric for GPU compressor performance rather than kernel-only throughput

CUSZP2 is evaluated on nine real-world HPC datasets on NVIDIA A100 and additional GPUs to measure throughput, compression ratio, memory bandwidth utilization, synchronization performance, and reconstructed data quality

CUSZP2 compresses each block by converting floats to quantization integers within a user error bound, then encodes blocks with either plain fixed-length or outlier fixed-length mode and concatenates blocks using a computed global prefix-sum
CUSZP2 performs compression and decompression entirely inside one GPU kernel to avoid CPU-GPU data movement and CPU synchronization overheads
CUSZP2 supports random access to compressed data at block granularity by storing block offsets and enabling indexed decompression with TB-level throughput

Outlier Fixed-Length Encoding stores a small outlier separately and per-element effective-bit lengths with a mode flag, and CUSZP2 selects outlier mode per block when it yields better compression ratio

Vectorized memory accesses use element-vector types to reduce memory instructions and arrange warp-level accesses to adjacent blocks to enable coalescing, increasing effective global memory throughput

Decoupled lookback allows thread blocks that would otherwise wait on serial device-level prefix-sum to perform lookback aggregation of predecessors, hiding synchronization latency and enabling TB-level progress overlap

Kernel-only throughput can be much higher than end-to-end throughput for CPU-GPU hybrid designs; measuring end-to-end (including cudaMemcpy and other GPU API overheads) gives a rigorous user-facing throughput metric
On NVIDIA A100 across nine HPC datasets CUSZP2 (both modes) achieves average end-to-end compression throughput of 332.42 GB/s and decompression throughput of 513.04 GB/s

CUSZP2 supports high-throughput random block access (measured average 1010.07 GB/s) and double-precision datasets with roughly 2x higher throughput than single precision due to identical lossless pipeline after quantization

Evaluation uses nine datasets from SDRBench and Open-SciVis and compares CUSZP2-P and CUSZP2-O to state-of-the-art pure-GPU compressors (cuZFP, FZ-GPU, cuSZp) using relative error bounds and fixed-rate settings
Evidence: Outlier-FLE gives higher compression ratios than plain-FLE on smooth datasets and CUSZP2-O achieves higher compression ratios than baselines in 24 of 27 evaluated cases

Evidence: Vectorization and coalescing raise measured GPU global memory throughput of CUSZP2 to ~1103-1175 GB/s on A100 (approaching 1555 GB/s peak), whereas other pure-GPU compressors measured 135-410 GB/s
Evidence: Decoupled lookback synchronization achieves 846.85 GB/s device-level synchronization throughput, 2.41x the plain chained-scan baseline

CUSZP2 outperforms state-of-the-art pure-GPU compressors by about 2x in end-to-end throughput and vastly outperforms CPU-GPU hybrid compressors (around 200x), while delivering better or equal compression ratios and preserving high reconstructed data quality for visualization
